discussion.content: This should be C. Business process interruption/downtime is very important and should be a factor when implementing any fix/change.

doesn't say what kind of corrective control needs to be implemented. And shouldn't business interruptions be the most inhibiting factor to applying any sort of corrective control? Why is a full desktop backup inhibiting the corrective control?
Full desktop rebuilds would lead to C...
Answer has got to be C as business interruption could lead to loss

comments.content: it also says "to applying the fix"

discussion.content: The question does clearly state "implement the corrective CONTROL", not "corrective action"... . Corrective controls are - among other things - restoring from backups. I'm still leaning more towards C than D on this... .

So many questions that don't seem to tally with the suggested answers. I'd say C too.. But do we have anyone who has actually taken the exam that can clarify this? Backups doesn't make sense to inhibit a fix
surely risk based approach.... Business interuption could stop any remediation?

questions.question_text: A security analyst positively identified the threat, vulnerability, and remediation. The analyst is ready to implement the corrective control. Which of the following would be the MOST inhibiting to applying the fix?

A security analyst is assisting in the redesign of a network to make it more secure. The solution should be low cost, and access to the secure segments should be easily monitored, secured, and controlled. Which of the following should be implemented?

discussion.content: Low cost... and secure... Jump box!
iSNT IT JUMP BOX FOR SPECIAL USERS ONLY? SUCH ADMINS

questions.question_text: A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) needs to ensure that a laptop image remains unchanged and can be verified before authorizing the deployment of the image to 4000 laptops. Which of the following tools would be appropriate to use in this case?

discussion.content: There are only two possible solutions: B. SHA1sum & C. FIM. Seeing as there is only "one" image, B would be better. FIM (File Integrity Monitoring) would be something applied to several files and it would be part of continuous monitoring.
this should be web servers and tls vpn services

comments.content:
Heartbleed is a vulnerability in the Openssl library which is being used by Web servers and TLS VPN Services. 

There are two types of VPN - IPSec and SSL. SSL based VPNs are the only ones who use open ssl which makes them vulnerable to heartbleed.
Yes, the answer is B & D.

discussion.content:
File integrity monitoring
File integrity monitoring (FIM) refers to an IT security process and technology that tests and checks operating system (OS), database, and application software files to determine whether or not they have been tampered with or corrupted.

questions.question_text: Which of the following systems or services is MOST likely to exhibit issues stemming from the Heartbleed vulnerability (Choose two.)

discussion.content: C and D. Unauthorized software since the security analyst doesn't know about it. Security analysts often have a list of approved applications they can compare newly discovered tools in the organization.

questions.question_text: In reviewing service desk requests, management has requested that the security analyst investigate the requests submitted by the new human resources manager. The requests consist of "unlocking" files that belonged to the previous human manager. The security analyst has uncovered a tool that is used to display five-level passwords. This tool is being used by several members of the service desk to unlock files. The content of these particular files is highly sensitive information pertaining to personnel. Which of the following BEST describes this scenario? (Choose two.)
